# 0: The '# n' attributes are used to write comments, to work around the
# 1: limitation that JSON files can't have inline comments. The number n
# 2: is used to make them unique, otherwise the editor compaons about
# 3: duplicate object key, and more annoyingly, the npm commands delete
name: openflowy-web

scripts.# 0: The scripts here are assumed to be run using Bash shell.
scripts.prebuild: echo === Running clean === && npm run clean
scripts.build: mkdir -p ./dist && cp -R src/index.html static/* dist/ && npx webpack --mode=development
scripts.prelive: echo === Running Build === && npm run build
scripts.# 1: Check: Are there any uncommitted files in Git staging area? Are there any modified files in Git? Are there any untracked files in Git?
scripts.prepublish-web-output: echo === Running pre-publish step and checks === && set -x && git diff --cached --exit-code && git diff --exit-code && ! git clean -n | read -n1 && npm run build
scripts.# 2: We do this dance to check-in the build output to a branch separate from development branch.
scripts.publish-web-output: rm -rf ../web-output/* && commit_hash=$(git log -1 --pretty=%H master) && pushd ../web-output && git checkout -f wen-output && popd && cp -R ./dist/. ../web-output/ && cd ../web-output/ && git add ./ && git commit -m "Updated build output using commit $commit_hash"
